body:
Could you please try out this workaround? Put all user JAR files on the outer class/module path, including the console launcher (standalone or not), in order to let application class loader keep a reference to them till the very end.

For example: `java -cp classes:lib/* org.junit.platform.console.ConsoleLauncher <ARGS>`

Here's a minimal reproducer without an external dependency, and without the standalone artifact. All required JAR files are stored in the `lib` subdirectory.
```java
class ShutdownTest {
  @org.junit.jupiter.api.Test
  void noop() {
    record Local() {}
    Runtime.getRuntime().addShutdownHook(new Thread(() -> System.out.println(Local.class)));
  }
}
```

```shell
javac -cp lib\* ShutdownTest.java
```

Works as expected, no error is thrown: 
```shell
java -cp .;lib\* org.junit.platform.console.ConsoleLauncher execute --scan-class-path
```

Fails as reported, `NoClassDefFoundError` is thrown:
```shell
java -cp lib\* org.junit.platform.console.ConsoleLauncher execute -cp . --scan-class-path
[...]
Exception in thread "Thread-1" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: ShutdownTest$1Local
        at ShutdownTest.lambda$noop$0(ShutdownTest.java:8)
        at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:1570)
Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: ShutdownTest$1Local
        at java.base/java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(URLClassLoader.java:445)
        at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:592)
        at java.base/java.net.FactoryURLClassLoader.loadClass(URLClassLoader.java:870)
        at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:525)
        ... 2 more
```

Note the difference in the commads where the `.` (current working directory) is added to the class path.

At the moment, I don't see solution to this issue, though. The convenient options offered by the JUnit Platform launcher ...
```
RUNTIME CONFIGURATION
      -cp, --classpath, --class-path=PATH
                             Provide additional classpath entries -- for example, for adding
                               engines and their dependencies. This option can be repeated.
```
... may only operate in the boundaries of the class loader world. It's unfortunate that the TestContainers extension installs a shutdown hook.

As there's already

- https://github.com/testcontainers/testcontainers-java/issues/1454

I tend to close this report as a 3rd-party issue.
Well, one option we have would be to _not_ close the `URLClassLoader` since the JVM is going to be shut down anyway and release its file handles. ðŸ¤”

Which is what we did before:

- https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1896

âž¡ Team discussion.
**Team decision:** Document that `java -cp` should be used instead of `java -jar ... execute -cp` when JVM shutdown hooks are involved.

> Well, one option we have would be to not close the URLClassLoader since the JVM is going to be shut down anyway and release its file handles

This would make sense.

> Which is what we did before

Why is it a problem _not_ to close the Classloader? It seems that file handles would be released anyway since the JVM is shutting down. Was there more to it than just "by the way we forgot `close()`"?

Here is a wild idea: how about "mocking" or capturing `addShutdownHook` in some way, and running all these hooks at the end of the test execution (to simulate the JVM shutdown from the test's perspective) but _before_ closing the classloader?

> Why is it a problem _not_ to close the Classloader?

Using the launcher multiple times in a single VM session led to memory and file handle leaks. The latter is a problme on Windows, as those non-closed JAR files couldn't be deleted between runs. Note that the launcher implements `ToolProvider` interface in order to allow multiple usages without spawning a new VM.

In addition, it's a resource the launcher creates/opens and the `URLClassLoader` implements `AutoCloseable`. It is meant to used in try-with-resources block - closing the resource gracefully when it's not longer needed.

> Here is a wild idea: how about "mocking" or capturing addShutdownHook in some way, and running all these hooks at the end of the test execution (to simulate the JVM shutdown from the test's perspective) but before closing the classloader?

No.

> Here is a wild idea: how about "mocking" or capturing `addShutdownHook` in some way, and running all these hooks at the end of the test execution (to simulate the JVM shutdown from the test's perspective) but _before_ closing the classloader?

I hope that resolving #1880 will remove the desire to register shutdown hooks in the future.

> Note that the launcher implements ToolProvider interface in order to allow usages without spawning a new VM.

Oh, I didn't know about this, so didn't realize several sessions could be run in a single JVM. But why would people do this instead of using the `junit-plaform-launcher` library? Is it to reuse listeners and code like this that is in the console artifact but not published as separate modules?

Then I would say it's even more important to properly run the application shutdown hooks between test sessions.

> > Here is a wild idea: how about "mocking" or capturing addShutdownHook in some way, and running all these hooks at the end of the test execution (to simulate the JVM shutdown from the test's perspective) but before closing the classloader?
> 
> No.

Well, that was harsh ðŸ˜† Could you please elaborate on why you think this wouldn't be a good thing?
